title: Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time in Hollywood gets theatrical re-release with FOUR NEW SCENES
text:
Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is heading back to theaters this weekend with four brand new scenes.

Sony Pictures announced on Wednesday that Once Upon a Time in Hollywood will be re-released in over 1,000 theaters on Friday, October 25.

The re-release will feature four new scenes that bookend the movie that add 10 additional minutes to the already lengthy run time of 141 minutes.

New scenes: Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is heading back to theaters this weekend with four brand new scenes

'Audiences have shown tremendous support for this movie, and we look forward to offering them another opportunity to see the film as it’s meant to be seen – in theaters on the big screen – with more sights and sounds of the sixties from Quentin Tarantino as an added treat, said Adrian Smith, President of Domestic Distribution, Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group.

Once Upon a Time in Hollywood opened with just over $41 million when it debuted at the end of July, the largest opening weekend in Tarantino's storied career.

The film went on to earn $139.8 million domestically and $368.3 million worldwide, from a $90 million budget.

Big hit: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood opened with just over $41 million when it debuted at the end of July, the largest opening weekend in Tarantino's storied career

Once Upon a Time in Hollywood's box office prowess was considered a big win for original films, since it was the only original movie this summer to crack $100 million domestic.

The film is set in the summer of 1969 in Hollywood, following iconic TV star Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his longtime stunt double Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt).

While they have both had success in the past, they make their way around an industry they hardly recognize anymore.

Friends: The film is set in the summer of 1969 in Hollywood, following iconic TV star Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his longtime stunt double Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt)

The massive ensemble cast also includes Margot Robbie as starlet Sharon Tate, who moves in next door to Dalton, Emile Hirsch as Jay Sebring, Al Pacino as Marvin Schwarz and rising star Margaret Qualley as Pussycat, to name a few.

Tarantino also own the New Beverly theater in Los Angeles, and fans who saw the film there were treated to an extended version of a Bounty Law segment, the TV show DiCaprio's Rick Dalton starred in.

Sony Pictures has not revealed what the four scenes that will be included in this new cut will feature quite yet.

Director and star: The massive ensemble cast also includes Margot Robbie as starlet Sharon Tate, who moves in next door to Dalton, Emile Hirsch as Jay Sebring, Al Pacino as Marvin Schwarz and rising star Margaret Qualley as Pussycat, to name a few

Despite the film's success, it has also seen its fair share of controversy, with the director coming under fire for his portrayal of Bruce Lee (Mike Moh).

Tarantino also recently made headlines for refusing to re-edit the film to appease censors in China, scrapping plans for a Chinese release of the film.

Variety's sources claim the Chinese release was put on hold after Bruce Lee's daughter Shannon Lee filed a complaint with China’s National Film Administration over the portrayal of her father in the film.
